Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analysis, Construction and Visualization of 3D Genome Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the three-dimensional (3D) structures of genomes. A 3D genome structure is critical for studying genome folding, genome function, and spatial gene regulation, but it has not been well studied in comparison with a one-dimensional (1D) linear genome. The main goal of this CAREER project is to design and develop contact-based computational methods to analyze, construct, and visualize 3D structures of genomes using chromosomal contact (interaction) data generated by genome conformation capturing techniques and next-generation DNA sequencing. The research data, methods and tools will provide materials to develop two new bioinformatics courses, integrating computational optimization, molecular structure modeling, genome sequencing, and genome annotation.

The successful completion of this project will produce a set of novel computational methods and bioinformatics tools to analyze, construct, and visualize 3D genome structures. The methods and tools will boost the study of genome structure, function, and gene regulation in the spatial context, which will have broad applications in almost every aspect of modern biological sciences in the post-genomic era. The research component will generate a rich set of new data and methods to train K1-12, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students. The wide dissemination of the two new bioinformatics courses will enrich the curriculum of bioinformatics, computational biology, computer science, large-scale constrained optimization, and molecular structure modeling. More information about the project is available at: http://www.cs.missouri.edu/~chengji/nsf_career.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The three-dimensional (3D) shape of genome plays an important role in various cellular function such as gene regulation, DNA replication, and cell development.  However, 3D genome shapes (or structures) have not been well studied due to lack of methods of measuring them. In this project, novel cutting-edge bioinformatics methods and tools were developed to construct high-quality 3D structures of chromosomes and genomes from chromosomal conformation data generated by next-generation DNA sequencing. A comprehensive user-friendly modeling software platform was created to facilitate the entire process of analyzing chromosomal conformation data, constructing 3D genome models, and applying them to biological problems. The first 3D genome structure database with a convenient web interface was developed to share thousands of 3D genome and chromosome structures with the community to advance biological research. In total, the research produces 25 journal publications, 30 presentations, abstracts, and posters, 11 open source bioinformatics tools and databases, 4 PhD dissertation, and 2 Master?s theses. The tools were widely disseminated as open source software packages and attracted a lot of users in the field. Moreover, two new courses on molecular structure modeling and computational optimization were created and established to integrate the research advances with the development of the graduate curriculum of bioinformatics and computational biology. 19 PhD, master?s, undergraduate, and high-school students including 5 under-represented students were trained on this project, which become the valuable workforce in 3D genomics and biotechnology. The 3D genome models and tools were also demonstrated for many middle- and high-school students, general public, and Missouri state legislature, which inspire the society?s awareness of the importance of 3D genomics on precision medicine, agriculture, biotechnology, and environment.
